fireeye-1.doc: Chinese cyber espionage operators modified the software packages of a legitimate vendor, NetSarang Computer, allowing access to a broad range of industries and institutions that include financial services, transportation, telecommunications, energy, media, academic, retail, and gaming. The malicious actors embedded a backdoor named SHADOWPAD, which can access network data and download additional malware. Based on shared communications infrastructure and similar targeting and tactics, FireEye Threat Intelligence assesses this activity is related to a Chinese espionage team that previously targeted a gaming company in 2015.

fireeye-2.doc: GREF Team is an innovative China-nexus cyber espionage operator that focuses on targeting energy, video game development studios, and high-tech companies in the U.S., South Korea, the Netherlands, Italy, France, and Japan. The group leverages a large library of malware tools, compromised digital certificates, and exploits. Besides being linked to a common supplier shared with other Chinese cyber espionage groups, GREF Team is believed to distribute its tools to other distinct China-based actors.

fireeye-3.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence uncovered GREF Team reusing a sender address from 2016 to target a European cryptocurrency exchange. GREF Team leveraged .NET malware that beacons to an IP address belonging to a South Korean University. This is the first time FireEye Threat Intelligence has uncovered GREF Team targeting financial entities, but it is consistent with our assessment that the team is involved in both financially motivated activity and cyber espionage on behalf of Chinese government interests.

fireeye-4.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence analyzed data sourced from a command and control (C&C) server running an application named "Werka," which is used by TrickBot for dynamic webinject administration and delivery. The Werka server delivers unique web injection code based on the presence of different gtags, or campaign identifiers, within requests made to the server. The manner in which this system operates suggests that each gtag value is associated with a different TrickBot customer. FireEye Threat Intelligence has identified and clustered a number of TrickBot gtag values found in the configuration of this system and has further found evidence to suggest that some associated TrickBot customers may be actively using other banking malware families, including Corebot, Danabot, Emotet, Gootkit, IcedID, Nymaim, TinyNuke, Ursnif, and Zeus Panda.

fireeye-5.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence discovered dozens of irregularities in the domain resolutions of government and commercial websites in the Middle East, North Africa, and Europe. Since 2017, DNS records were altered, and fraudulent Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) certificates were created for more than 100 domains in order to redirect and intercept website traffic and steal valid credentials and emails. FireEye Threat Intelligence has been unable to attribute these unauthorized changes to a tracked group; however, the targeting and limited technical evidence are consistent with Iranian actors. It is also likely that more than one actor has used this technique.

fireeye-6.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence has observed evidence of an actor(s) leveraging GitHub to host a variety of malware for campaigns that appear to be targeting entities in Russia for financial gain. Despite recent reporting indicating that these campaigns are distributing Buhtrap, we have not observed direct evidence of Buhtrap payloads being delivered in these operations. We anticipate that this actor(s) will continue conducting operations for at least the near term. However, due to the variety of different malware families these operations have employed, it is possible that this actor(s) will adopt additional malware variants in future operations.

fireeye-7.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence developed an Operational Technology Cyber Security Incident Ontology (OT-CSIO) to classify different types of attacks, facilitate cross-case analysis, and provide guidance for assessing risks. It consists of high-level analysis and is not meant to provide in-depth insights into the nuances of each incident. Our methodology evaluates four categories, which are target, sophistication, impact, and affected equipment architecture based on the Purdue Model (18-00020979). The OT-CSIO evaluates the full attack lifecycle and does not describe the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) implemented at each step of the incident.

fireeye-8.doc: Continued examination revealed multiple distinct clusters within the previously reported DNS manipulation activity. Cluster A uses phishing and TWOTONE malware, and Cluster B appears to use web exploits and penetration testing frameworks to gain initial access to victim networks. Actors responsible for Cluster B interrupted operations after an emergency directive was published by the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) on Jan. 22, 2019, but we cannot definitively say that this publication caused the change in operations. However, FireEye Threat Intelligence discovered Cluster B victims leveraging new infrastructure since then.

fireeye-9.doc: FireEye devices detected and blocked a likely Iranian group using a compromised email account to target a Lebanese insurance company using TWOTONE malware and newly registered command and control (C&C) infrastructure. The compromised email account belongs to a Lebanese insurance company which experienced DNS hijacking activity Nov. 28, 2018. FireEye Threat Intelligence found a related phishing document impersonating a UK university and domains spoofing an Indian outsourcing firm.

fireeye-10.doc: In late March 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed UPS- and invoice-themed campaigns delivering Emotet via links leading to ZIP archives containing macro-laden Word documents or JavaScript. This is a departure from its historical tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs); most commonly, campaigns have leveraged macro document attachments or links leading to macro documents. FireEye Threat Intelligence also observed changes in the way Emotet communicates through HTTP POST requests with its command and control (C&C) servers. These changes were likely made to evade host and network-based detection mechanisms, although it would be easy for security product vendors to adapt to these changes.

fireeye-11.doc: A supply chain compromise first reported in March 2019 distributed CRACKSHOT and DEADEYE downloaders primarily to victims in Southeast Asia. We surmise the incident is linked to similar previously reported supply chain compromises affecting entities in East Asia, although the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) demonstrate a greater effort to evade detection and hinder analysis when compared to the older campaigns.

fireeye-12.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence has been tracking a fast-flux bulletproof hosting infrastructure internally named "Fluxxy" (aka DarkCloud) that has been active since at least late 2009.The actor(s) associated with the bulletproof hosting service use the moniker "Ccweb" and have advertised the bulletproof hosting service on exploit.in since 2010, with the notable addition of fast-flux in 2012. The actor "Sollhost" is believed to be a verified reseller of Fluxxy offering the service under the name of "Sollhost bulletproof hosting." FireEye Threat Intelligence has observed significant interest in Fluxxy by a large number of actors. The related infrastructure has been leveraged for various types of malicious activity, including numerous malware operations, phishing sites, and card shops; we assess with high confidence that actors will continue using this service.

fireeye-13.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a cluster of activity that began in April 2019 and continued through June 2019 that leveraged web-based attacks including the SharePoint vulnerability CVE-2019-0604 to target financial institutions in Turkey and Southeast Asia. Based on overlaps in infrastructure and targeting, we assess with low confidence this campaign is affiliated with TEMP.Shadow (aka EmpireMonkey) and is likely financially motivated. We anticipate the actors responsible for this operation will continue targeting financial institutions for the foreseeable future; however, the actors may shift at least some tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) in future operations.

adversary: the actors responsible for this operation
victim: financial institutions in Turkey and Southeast Asia

fireeye-15.doc: Since June 7, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence has observed a complete cessation of Emotet-related spam distribution activity. The inactivity of Emotet distribution operations is supported by evidence observed across the FireEye sensor network and active monitoring of the Emotet botnet. The cause for this current cessation of activity is unclear, and it is not known whether this period of inactivity will lead to a permanent change in Emotet operations, though we continue to proactively monitor the situation.

fireeye-17.doc: On May 14, 2019, FireEye devices detected spear-phishing emails attempting to direct victims to Dropbox folders to deliver the TAILCOAT payload. The emails were sent to employees at several European missions to Palestine and related diplomatic entities in the region and leveraged Palestinian-themed lure content. While attribution is unclear, tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) and targeting is consistent with previously reported Molerats Team activity.

victim: employees at several European missions to Palestine
related diplomatic entities in the region

fireeye-18.doc: On July 11, 2019, the Security Service of Ukraine announced the arrest of Mykhailo Rytikov, who they allege has operated a bulletproof hosting service since at least 2007 using the monikers "Whost," "Webhost," and "абдула," among others. FireEye Threat Intelligence observed actors complain that their servers were offline on the date of the arrest, and other actors began questioning whether the Whost username had been taken over by law enforcement. However, forum administrators have since verified the moniker's legitimacy, suggesting that at least some individuals behind the Whost service may be continuing to operate. While the arrest of Rytikov may cause a temporary cessation in some malicious activity using Whost, it is unlikely to have a significant impact long-term as actors can easily shift to alternative hosting providers to support their operations.

fireeye-19.doc: In June 2019, the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) released a special publication draft that expands the cyber security requirements imposed on certain U.S. Department of Defense (DoD) contractors. The publication includes an explicit requirement to either segment operational technology (OT) or ensure the devices are compliant with imposed cyber security requirements. The inclusion of OT-specific requirements in an information technology (IT)-dominate cyber security standard demonstrates the pertinence of OT and an increased level of awareness by cyber security regulators. We also stress that segmentation is a necessary yet insufficient step toward securing OT networks.

fireeye-20.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence assesses with moderate confidence that a suspected fabricated letter advocating for the overthrow of the Russian Government, purportedly authored by U.S. Senator Ben Cardin, is being leveraged as part of a broader pro-Russia information operation primarily being run across various Russian and Ukrainian blogs and online forums. While the vast majority of the identified activity is being conducted on forums and blog sites, we have also observed a Reddit account and a small number of suspected inauthentic Facebook accounts promote the activity. The FireEye Threat Intelligence investigation, which has thus far identified activity occurring as recently as July 2, 2019, adds to findings by the Atlantic Council's Digital Forensic Research Lab (DFRLab) published in June 2019, which exposed similar activity occurring in 2018 and early 2019. We assess with high confidence that the broader operation frequently leverages forged correspondence between high-level government officials.

fireeye-21.doc: On July 12, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a phishing campaign that delivered the COOLPANTS backdoor using financial transaction-themed lures. The emails in this campaign included indicators and targeting typical of past suspected TEMP.Splinter campaigns and delivered a COOLPANTS payload that used command and control (C&C) infrastructure overlapping with a past suspected TEMP.MetaStrike campaign. While COOLPANTS is believed to be private to TEMP.MetaStrike, this malware has been delivered in multiple previous campaigns that exhibit delivery methods and targeting characteristic of TEMP.Splinter. Plausible scenarios that may explain this include TEMP.Splinter acting as a delivery service, all observed activity being carried out by TEMP.MetaStrike, or intermittent cooperation between the two groups.

fireeye-22.doc: In May 2019, FireEye devices detected and blocked a spear-phishing campaign likely targeting Ukrainian government entities distributing the ARMEDCLOUD malware attributed to TEMP.Armageddon. Additional samples and related infrastructure were subsequently uncovered. This newest version of ARMEDCLOUD contains anti-forensic features.

fireeye-23.doc: After a brief cessation of Qakbot activity in early July 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed Qakbot activity resume on July 16 and incorporate an updated version of the password grabber module. The latest version of the password grabber module includes debug strings that reveal names of internal functions and the name of the module itself (plugin_passgrabber).One of the most notable aspects of the update is the inclusion of two embedded URLs that were seen leading to the download of a version of Mimikatz that appears to be unique to Qakbot.

fireeye-24.doc: Beginning on July 18, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed Amadey campaigns that closely resembled previous Chanitor campaigns and delivered Cobalt Strike Beacon, Pony, SendSafe, and Ursnif. Based on multiple overlaps in the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used throughout these campaigns, we have high confidence that at least one of the actors associated with the Chanitor distribution network has begun using AMADEY malware in campaigns as a replacement for Chanitor. While these campaigns appear to be related to prior Chanitor campaigns, there were notable difference beyond its replacement with AMADEY that suggest the actors behind this operation are experimenting with new TTPs.

fireeye-26.doc: While overlaps exist in the tools and methodologies used to perform reconnaissance in information technology (IT) and operational technology (OT) environments, the information required for a targeted attack on OT systems is unique. Organizations should identify their unique attack surfaces, the value of their OT information to the adversary, and how the information can be used in the context of a tailored attack. Controlling and protecting this information should be a priority for denying adversary reconnaissance efforts.

infrastructure: information technology (IT) and operational technology (OT) environments

fireeye-27.doc: In late July 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed a campaign using various delivery mechanisms to deliver KAYSLICE and COOLPANTS. Observed recipients included individuals at financial organizations based in Russia and Slovakia. Based on the use of overlapping tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we assess with moderate confidence that the recent KAYSLICE/COOLPANTS campaign can be attributed to TEMP.MetaStrike (aka Cobalt Group).

victim: individuals at financial organizations based in Russia and Slovakia

fireeye-28.doc: On July 25, 2019, City Power Johannesburg announced that their information technology (IT) systems were infected with a ransomware virus that encrypted their "databases, applications and networks. " The attack on Johannesburg-based City Power prevented customers on pay-as-you-go plans from purchasing electricity. FireEye Threat Intelligence has recently observed various cases of ransomware infections on IT systems resulting in disruptions or outages to production despite no impact to operational technology (OT) networks (19-00012368). City Power's incident is the first instance we have observed where customers lost access to energy as a result of malware infections in corporate networks. We suggest that organizations with high-availability requirements evaluate their safety and business risks related to ransomware attacks.

fireeye-29.doc: Security researchers identified 11 vulnerabilities in the VxWorks real-time operating system (RTOS) developed by Wind River. The collection of vulnerabilities is dubbed "Urgent/11." RTOS have specialized kernels that minimize interruptions to critical system processes. VxWorks is the most common RTOS and can be found in embedded systems used in a wide variety of industries, including aerospace and defense, automotive, consumer electronics, industrial automation, medical devices, and network/computer infrastructure. Asset owners are encouraged to apply the latest patches released by Wind River. Alternative mitigations, such as firewall rules, intrusion detection signatures, or OS-version upgrades, can be deployed as countermeasures in the absence of patches.

fireeye-30.doc: On July 29, 2019, Capital One announced a data security incident in which an unauthorized actor accessed personal information of over 100 million individuals in the United States and approximately 6 million in Canada who applied for Capital One credit card products between 2005 and early 2019. Paige Adele Thompson, who was arrested in Washington state in association with the breach, exploited a firewall misconfiguration that allowed her to gain access to folders or buckets of data in Capital One's cloud storage space. Currently, the motivation for the attack is uncertain, but the brazenness with which she discussed her activities may suggest that she was at least in part motivated by ego or other factors. The vast amount of data stored in the cloud from many different sources makes systems and data hosted by cloud services providers attractive targets, and we anticipate actors will continue targeting and abusing cloud services for the foreseeable future.

victim: 100 million individuals in the United States

fireeye-31.doc: FireEye devices blocked the attempted download of a SOGU payload at a Hong Kong-based media organization. Based on infrastructure overlap and similarities in tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we believe this activity is likely related to previous Chinese espionage operations leveraging SOGU and HIGHNOON malware. We note that this activity will likely continue in the short to medium term and that media and civil society organizations in the region remain at risk of targeting with SOGU malware.

victim: media and civil society organizations in the region

fireeye-32.doc: In April 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence reported on a network of suspected inauthentic news sites and social media accounts, aimed at audiences globally, conducting influence activity supportive of the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and critical of its regional rivals, Qatar and Iran. We surmised that the network was being operated by a marketing firm in India on behalf of actors seeking to support UAE political interests. We have continued to identify additional activity that we believe is being conducted by this network, including the leveraging of personas on additional social media platforms to promote political narratives. The personas have promoted narratives, specific to their regions of focus, that reflect UAE political interests. For example, we observed accounts posing as individuals from Turkey promote messaging critical of the Turkish Justice and Development (AKP) party and supportive of Ekrem İmamoğlu, the then-opposition candidate for Istanbul mayor, ahead of the Istanbul mayoral elections that occurred on June 23.

fireeye-33.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence uncovered a malicious profiling script on the website of an Armenian think tank in June 2019. The website redirects to a second compromised domain hosting a WITCHCOVEN profiling script. WITCHCOVEN has been used by Russia-nexus Turla since 2014 to collect detailed web browser information and install a persistent tracking cookie. The compromised domain also hosted a sample of the new WHIPSNAP backdoor.

fireeye-34.doc: FireEye technical analysts examined two APT32 archives leveraging Singapore conference-themed filenames and decoy documents to target unknown victims. At least one sample was hosted on Dropbox and likely delivered through a malicious link embedded in a phishing email. Following victim initialization of the executable contained in the archive, the infection process leads to installation of a FREIGHTBOX dropper and a BEACON payload.

fireeye-36.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence analyzed a malicious macro document targeting a U.S.-based water and power utility company in late July 2019. The unknown threat actor leveraged skilled social engineering techniques and LOOKBACK malware. The macro document bears superficial similarities to public FireEye Threat Intelligence reporting on UPPERCUT activity. Entities in the utilities sector are likely at risk of targeting in the short- to medium-term and should remain vigilant.

victim: U.S.-based water and power utility company

fireeye-37.doc: A newly identified downloader, referred to by FireEye Threat Intelligence as BULLZLINK, demonstrates a number of overlaps with malware developed and offered by badbullzvenom. During July 2019, two campaigns were identified using this downloader, including a NETWIRE campaign attributed to TEMP.Splinter and a likely SQUIDSLEEP/SQUIDGATE campaign that has not yet been attributed to a specific threat actor group. Based upon these observations, we assess with moderate confidence that badbullzvenom is continuing to develop new tools for use by financially motivated threat actors.

fireeye-38.doc: In August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified campaigns leveraging a modified version of SmokeLoader that bypasses the normal SmokeLoader pay-per-update business model. This modified version of the malware has been patched by editing existing binaries to communicate with updated command and control (C&C) URLs. While we have not yet observed any actors publicly advertising this modified version of SmokeLoader for sale, it is plausible that actors could sell this version of the malware for significantly less than the original version of SmokeLoader.

fireeye-39.doc: During a compromise of a hospitality organization, which we attribute to FIN7, the attackers deployed various malicious payloads, including CARBANAK, BABYMETAL, and the PILLOWMINT point-of-sale (POS) malware. Notably, in this incident, FIN7 leveraged a seemingly compromised email account belonging one of the victim's suppliers to send a password-protected GRIFFON document to a restaurant manager. FIN7's shift to engaging in third-party compromise attacks marks a significant evolution in the group's operations and the manner in which organizations need to protect themselves against their attacks.

fireeye-40.doc: Since the December 2018 indictment of multiple APT10 actors, monitoring of numerous attack surfaces, sensitive-source feeds, public repositories, and open-source reporting has not resulted in the detection of new APT10 activity. Based on prior operational characteristics, we continue to assess with low confidence that the group has reduced operational visibility and will return after a period of dormancy. However, the actors themselves may have been reassigned or relieved from their contracts. Operators previously associated with APT10 may have returned as part of different APT missions working on behalf of the People's Republic of China Ministry of State Security (MSS). APT10 was known for having shifted over to publicly available tools and either using them as-is or only slightly modifying them. Their last activity before the indictment was largely QUASSARRAT, BEACON, and UPPERCUT. Previously, each time that APT10 has reemerged after a lull, the group has largely shifted over to new sets of public or shared tools.

adversary: People's Republic of China Ministry of State Security (MSS)

fireeye-41.doc: On Aug. 5, 2019, Twitter account @BelangerPolice, an account posing as a Toronto police inspector, posted tweets alleging that U.S. National Security Advisor John Bolton was involved with money laundering through transactions involving the Iranian opposition group People's Mojahedin Organization of Iran (MEK). Toronto Police confirmed that the account, now suspended, was inauthentic. While we are currently unable to provide attribution for the @BelangerPolice account, its activity and promoted narratives are consistent with what we have observed from pro-Iran information operations. We identified a Twitter account posing as a "freelance journalist" that we surmise was created to promote the Belanger content, along with other material pertaining to John Bolton. We identified a second Twitter account posing as a "freelance journalist" replying to a @BelangerPolice tweet that we surmise is an inauthentic persona. However, we do not have attribution or motive for this account at this time.

fireeye-42.doc: South Asian government entities were targeted with BREEZESUGAR malware in a spear-phishing campaign on June 12, 2019.Although attribution is unclear, we have previously seen similar activity in campaigns leveraging EVILNUGGET, which we believe is used by Chinese actors. Governments and military entities in South Asia remain at risk of targeting by this actor and BREEZESUGAR malware.

victim: Governments and military entities in South Asia

fireeye-43.doc: In August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a campaign in which malicious actors targeted customers of two Mexican banks with a customized variant of the KL Remota banking malware. Based on overlaps in the attacker infrastructure, we assess with high confidence that this recent campaign was conducted by a Mexican threat actor who has been active for more than four years. There are multiple indications that Brazilian malware developer(s) provided the Mexican threat actor with a customized variant of the KL Remota for use in operations targeting Mexican financial institutions. The relationship highlights Brazilian malware developers' interest in broadening the scope of their operations and their willingness to engage actors or groups from other countries for monetary gains.

fireeye-44.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence recently observed a malicious email campaign targeting multiple organizations across North America and Europe and delivering FLAWEDAMMYYY payloads. This activity has overlaps with a financially motivated actor dubbed TEMP.Warlock, which has been seen at multiple intrusions where we have attributed the latter-stage operations to FIN6 and FIN7. While the targeted organizations observed in this recent spam campaign do not resemble traditional financial, retail, or hospitality targets, we consider this event significant because of recent trends in which relatively sophisticated financially motivated threat actors are pivoting to ransomware and extortion to monetize their network intrusion efforts.

fireeye-46.doc: APT41, a cyber espionage operation aligned with Chinese interests, is using MESSAGETAP malware to parse and log SMS data at a telecommunications company. MESSAGETAP leverages a keyword list to identify messages of interest, including those related to internal security issues and military ranks. The campaign exemplifies Chinese espionage efforts to collect information from further upstream in global network traffic flow instead of at the level of targeted organizations or individual end users.

adversary: a cyber espionage operation aligned with Chinese interests

fireeye-47.doc: In mid-August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified multiple files that were being used to deliver the COOLPANTS backdoor. While we have not yet identified any phishing emails associated with this campaign, there is some indication the activity impacted an organization in Moldova, although targeting was likely broader than observed. Based on the use of overlapping tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we assess with low confidence that the recent KAYSLICE/COOLPANTS campaign can be attributed to TEMP.MetaStrike (aka Cobalt Group).

fireeye-48.doc: An unidentified actor targeted coalition forces, media outlets, government entities, and humanitarian aid organizations in a spear-phishing campaign in late July 2019. The emails leveraged "Youth in Afghanistan"-related lure content and contained a malicious Word document with additional decoy content to deliver a variant of xRAT malware to the targeted systems. We currently lack sufficient information to attribute this activity to a specific actor.

fireeye-49.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a North Korean defector-themed spear-phishing campaign likely targeting entities and individuals with an interest in inter-Korean border issues with Windows and Android variants of DOGCALL malware. Based on overlaps in tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), the use of DOGCALL malware, and the targeting of individuals with an interest in the cross-border conflict, we assess with high confidence that this activity is conducted by APT37. Entities and researchers with an interest in inter-Korean border issues remain at risk of targeting with DOGCALL malware in the short to medium term.

fireeye-50.doc: In mid-August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified malicious URLs hosting HTA files that, if navigated to, resulted in the download of PowerShell Empire; links to these HTA files were posted on a Canadian stock forum messaging board. Based on overlaps in the attacker infrastructure, regional targeting, and the tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used throughout this recent activity and prior FIN10 campaigns, we have high confidence this activity can be attributed to FIN10. This recent campaign suggests that FIN10 continues to employ familiar TTPs, and we anticipate that these operations will persist in the near term.

fireeye-52.doc: Screenshots leaked in June 2019 suggest Lebanese entities were targeted with DUALTONE malware, a .NET variant of TWOTONE, called Karkoff by its author. Submissions of DUALTONE samples to a public malware repository suggest a global port operator in Lebanon was likely also targeted with DUALTONE malware in March 2019. Based on targeting consistencies, samples uploaded to public malware repositories, and technical indicators, we assess with high confidence that APT34 is responsible for this activity and that related entities remain at risk of DUALTONE malware targeting.

fireeye-53.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a botnet panel named "X-Key" on a malicious IP server. The command and control (C&C) server hosts the XKEYLOG malware, a keylogger that is also capable of taking screenshots. Among the files obtained from the sever is a screenshot of a human-machine interface (HMI) used to monitor Sulphur Recovery Units (SRUs). We believe the actor inadvertently accessed the HMI while searching for point-of-sale (POS) systems to facilitate credit card theft. The identification of this HMI screenshot highlights the continued accessibility of such systems by relatively unsophisticated threat actors. We recommend that companies conduct regular scans of their IP ranges to determine if any of their control systems are directly connected to the internet.

fireeye-54.doc: The Emotet botnet ceased its spam operations and distribution of secondary payloads between early June 2019 and mid-August 2019. Beginning on Aug. 21, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed several Emotet controllers delivering modules to existing bots. These controllers had been seen in previous Emotet operations. New Emotet samples were identified on Sept. 9, 2019, that contained new command and control (C&C) infrastructure. FireEye Threat Intelligence has not yet identified any malicious email campaigns distributing Emotet, however, the presence of new infrastructure further suggests the Emotet botnet will return to full operation in the near future.

fireeye-55.doc: In July 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a server hosting a collection of tools, including newly identified variants of two point-of-sale (POS) malware families, each of which were previously associated with only one distinct threat actor group, FIN7 or FIN8. While the exact nature of the relationship between the groups and their tools may be more easily assessed as activity continues, the presence of both FIN7 and FIN8 tools on the same server suggests that either some tools are not unique to the respective threat groups or some overlap exists between their associated actors. The server also contained a newly identified Ursnif variant we are tracking as SAIGON and two new malware families we are tracking as FLIPSWITCH and WOOLSOCKS. Analysis of the malware is ongoing and will be updated as additional information is uncovered. This observed activity is significant because it provides evidence of business relationships among criminal groups, which may enable the groups to attain higher levels of technical sophistication or to tackle larger projects.

fireeye-57.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a different variant of SCRAPMINT that has no exfiltration mechanism, does not communicate over the network, and expects a filename to be passed as an argument. This variant of SCRAPMINT was hosted on a server that also hosted multiple other point-of-sale (POS) malware and public tools. FireEye Threat Intelligence was able to gain additional insights into the threat actors' post-compromise activities preceding the deployment of SCRAPMINT from an XKEYLOG server. The modification of SCRAPMINT allows for smaller and less complex malware and gives actors the ability to deploy a separate exfiltration tool more suitable for a given victim environment.

fireeye-58.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence identified a BIODISK binary designed to compromise fingerprint-secured USB drives and may be used to infiltrate air-gapped networks. The BIODISK binary targeted a government and defense entity in the Asia-Pacific region. While attribution is unclear, the threat actor is highly sophisticated and likely conducted extensive reconnaissance against the victim environment.

fireeye-59.doc: In late August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence identified two waves of a phishing campaign that delivered KAYSLICE and COOLPANTS and leveraged domains spoofing Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT) and the European Central Bank. Based on overlaps in infrastructure and observed tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), we assess with moderate confidence that this recent activity can be attributed to TEMP.MetaStrike. The most recent campaign employed two new delivery TTPs that were not observed in previous TEMP.MetaStrike campaigns, including the use of weaponized browser updates and IMG files to deliver malicious JavaScript and LNK files. The changes are consistent with our previous assessments that TEMP.MetaStrike regularly shifts its TTPs to remain undetected and increase the effectiveness of its campaigns.

victim: Society for Worldwide Interbank Financial Telecommunication (SWIFT)

fireeye-60.doc: In August 2019, Belarusian media outlets reported that a rogue electronic device was found under the server room of a paper mill in Svetlogorsk, Belarus. The device is allegedly capable of remotely damaging manufacturing processes and server equipment by causing a short circuit. Sources claim the device was planted by CAMCE, a Chinese contractor constructing the mill. CAMCE is also accused of extracting license keys from servers, deleting control logic, and dismantling a turbine control cable. While our independent research sheds doubt on the accuracy of this reporting, the incident highlights the unusually high risk sometimes posed by corporate entities and insiders. Organizations should audit third parties to detect potential illegitimate activity, particularly when contracts involve industrial safety and reliability design features.

infrastructure: server room of a paper mill in Svetlogorsk, Belarus

fireeye-61.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence observed a spear-phishing campaign targeting entities in the virtual currency exchange sector with SOGU malware in June 2019. The activity leveraged Windows Control Panel objects to download and execute a SOGU payload on the victim's system. Similar entities in the virtual currency exchange sector and the financial services industry remain at risk of targeting by SOGU malware in the short to medium term.

victim: Similar entities in the virtual currency exchange sector and the financial services industry
entities in the virtual currency exchange sector

fireeye-62.doc: In late August 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed an email campaign delivering PACKETSPLIT and WSHRAT. The campaign appeared to impact financial services organizations based in Southeast Asia, although targeting may have been broader than what was directly observed. We have high confidence that this recent campaign can be attributed to TEMP.Splinter based on overlaps in tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) with prior campaigns.

victim: financial services organizations based in Southeast Asia

fireeye-65.doc: In April and May 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence reported on a network of social media accounts that we assessed were operating in support of Iranian interests that included accounts impersonating U.S. politicians and pretending to be journalists. In August 2019, we observed a resumption of activity by one of these accounts, which had been inactive since late May following the suspension of much of the rest of network. We have additionally identified what we believe is a related network of at least 20 inauthentic Twitter accounts conducting activity nearly identical to that of the reactivated account, predominantly the messaging directed at U.S. Representatives promoting specific narratives aligned with Iranian political interests.

fireeye-66.doc: On Sept. 4, 2019, the North American Electric Reliability Corporation (NERC) released a "Lessons Learned" report providing additional details regarding a denial-of-service (DoS) incident that impacted a U.S. utility on March 5, 2019. The incident resulted from the exploitation of known vulnerabilities in firewall web interfaces. While the outages resulted in no major impacts to energy generation, the incident highlights that internet-connected perimeter devices—even in low-impact bulk electric systems (BES)—may expose networks to disruption or degradation threats. FireEye Threat Intelligence suggests that asset owners avoid internet connectivity for perimeter devices whenever feasible, configure firewalls to deny any traffic not explicitly allowed, and perform regular vulnerability assessments.

fireeye-67.doc: An ongoing spear-phishing campaign distributing the SOURCANDLE downloader has been targeting Japanese chemicals manufacturers since July 2019. Although we have no indications of direct intellectual property (IP) theft, cyber espionage operations targeting chemicals manufacturers may enable strategic decision making, especially amidst unstable market conditions.

fireeye-68.doc: The Emotet botnet ceased its spam operations and distribution of secondary payloads between early June 2019 and mid-August 2019. While we began to see limited Emotet activity beginning on Aug. 21, 2019, no spam campaigns had been identified. On Sept. 16, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed Emotet resume spamming using both German and English lures. Additionally, we identified secondary TrickBot and Ursnif (Gozi-ISFB) payloads being downloaded. There does not appear to be any notable evolution to the botnet's tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs), although we are continuing to analyze the recently observed Emotet executables to identify any changes.

fireeye-70.doc: In late August 2019, the actor "dihlofoss" posted a complaint against another actor using the handle "shitscrazy." According to this complaint, shitscrazy owed a significant amount of debt for "cashed transfers. "This recent complaint, as well as shitscrazy's other observed activities within the underground community, provides some evidence that shitscrazy has provided cashout services for the operators of the Dridex malware. Actor shitscrazy has shown consistent interest in multiple types of malicious activity within the past several years, and we expect this actor's activities will continue to pose a threat to organizations in diverse sectors and regions.

fireeye-71.doc: The SAKABOTA toolkit has targeted Middle Eastern government entities since late 2017 and may be used by an actor loosely tied to APT34. SAKABOTA is a modular .NET toolkit capable of leveraging additional payloads such as DIEZEN, SAKABOTA Eye, HISOKA, and LINKHIDE malware. Organizations that have previously been targeted by Iran-nexus espionage operations and government, financial, and consulting entities in the Middle East remain at high risk of targeting.

fireeye-73.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence has identified a network of suspected inauthentic accounts on Twitter and Facebook promoting content from the news site "The BL" (thebl.com) as well as political material in support of U.S. President Trump. The BL appears to be a legitimate news site that maintains pages in English, Chinese, Spanish, Portuguese, and Vietnamese. We have observed indications that The BL is linked to The Epoch Times and to The Sound of Hope Radio Network, media organizations that open sources have reported as linked to the Falun Gong (also known as Falun Dafa) movement. The practice of Falun Gong has been banned in China since 1999. Media outlets recently reported that Facebook banned The Epoch Times from future advertising on its platform due to alleged violations of its advertisement policies.

fireeye-74.doc: A suspected APT33 campaign leveraged spoofed U.S. defense contractor domains to deliver POSHC2 and KOADIC malware. The domain naming conventions and an associated webpage advertise career opportunities in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, with specific defense contractors. While the precise method of distribution of the suspected payloads remains unclear, a trusted third party has reported targeted emails associated with the domains.

infrastructure: domain naming conventions and an associated webpage

fireeye-75.doc: Based on newly obtained intelligence on infrastructure, FireEye Threat Intelligence is investigating the potential involvement of the Russia-nexus intrusion groups Sandworm Team and APT28 in two influence operations targeting Ukraine and Lithuania in 2018 and early 2019. The first operation was conducted in January 2018 with a compromise of the Ukrainian aircraft manufacturer Antonov's website and the publication of a fabricated letter written as if by Antonov's management with a narrative critical of the Ukrainian government. The second operation was conducted in April 2019, with the posting of a false article to the website of the Lithuanian news outlet "Kas Vyksta Kaune," stating that the Lithuanian Minister of Defense was suspected of corruption.

fireeye-77.doc: Recent open-source reports describe new MANGOPUNCH activity targeting U.S. military personnel and Saudi Arabian information technology (IT) providers. FireEye Threat Intelligence observations, in conjunction with public disclosures, reveal a number of samples suggesting renewed Iran-nexus operations using MANGOPUNCH. While we have previously seen APT35 use MANGOPUNCH during intrusions in 2017, FireEye Threat Intelligence is withholding attribution at this time until more evidence becomes available.

fireeye-78.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence  identified multiple modified TRITON framework executables uploaded to a malware analysis sandbox in September 2019. While the modified executables were apparently uploaded by a researcher, their release confirms our assessment and highlights that publicly available TRITON code can be used to develop new tools for intrusion. Targeted industrial control system (ICS) attack frameworks—like TRITON—can be difficult to scale because of the unique design of networks for different organizations. However, we highlight that access to this improved code can serve as a blueprint for future ICS attack frameworks.

fireeye-80.doc: On Sept. 30, 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed bots associated with TrickBot and IcedID receive identical commands to download a file. This file appeared to be a variant of the GlobeImpsoter ransomware based on publicly reported tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) associated with this ransomware family. The activity highlights a recent trend in which a rising number of threat actors have incorporated ransomware into their operations presumably to diversify monetization tactics and achieve higher profits.

fireeye-81.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence has identified a network of accounts on Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, and YouTube that we assess with moderate confidence are operating in a coordinated and inauthentic manner to push narratives in support of the Cuban Government and critical of the U.S.We assess with varying confidence levels that some of these accounts are using artificial intelligence (AI)-generated "deepfake" images as profile photos.

fireeye-83.doc: Throughout late September and early October 2019, FireEye Threat Intelligence observed multiple phishing campaigns delivering KAYSLICE and COOLPANTS malware. Based on overlaps in infrastructure and observed targeting, we assess with moderate confidence that this recent activity can be attributed to TEMP.MetaStrike. We also identified overlaps between the TTPs used in these recent campaigns and an unattributed COOLPANTS campaign that occurred in mid-September 2019.

fireeye-84.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence uncovered a modified sample of the Russia-nexus Turla Team XTRANS malware, dubbed NETTRANS, likely targeting Brazilian entities in August 2019. Like XTRANS, NETTRANS communicates via encoded JPEG files sent via email for command and control (C&C). It is unclear whether NETTRANS is intended to supplement or replace XTRANS and under what conditions each might be deployed.

capability: modified sample of the Russia-nexus Turla Team XTRANS malware

fireeye-85.doc: FireEye Threat Intelligence discovered infrastructure leveraged by a suspected Iran-nexus actor to scan or compromise targets in the U.S., Israel, Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates (UAE), and others. The actor's activities were primarily focused on exploiting vulnerabilities in Pulse Connect Secure VPN or Fortinet FortiOS VPN applications.

bleeping-1.doc:
A new CryptoMix, or CryptFile2, variant called Revenge has been discovered by Broad Analysis that is being distributed via the RIG exploit kit.   This variant contains many similarities to its predecessor CryptoShield, which is another CryptoMix variant, but includes some minor changes that are described below.
 As a note, in this article I will be referring to this infection as the Revenge Ransomware as that will most likely be how the victim's refer to it. It is important to remember, though, that this ransomware is not a brand new infection, but rather a new version of the CryptoMix ransomware family.
 How Victim's Become Infected with the Revenge Ransomware
 Both BroadAnalysis.com and Brad Duncan, of Malware-Traffic-Analysis.net, have seen Revenge being distributed through web sites that have been hacked so that the RIG Exploit Kit javascript is added pages on the site.

bleeping-2.doc:
WhatsApp and Telegram have patched their respective web clients against a common security flaw discovered by researchers from Israeli firm Check Point, a security issue that would have allowed an attacker to take over user accounts and spy on conversations or steal user account data.
 According to researchers, the entry point was an attacker's ability to upload and send malicious code hidden inside HTML files.
 Both WhatsApp and Telegram would show a preview image for these links, making users believe they were accessing a video or image.
 Exploit granted attackers access to browser's localStorage
 In reality, when users clicked the links, malicious JavaScript code contained in the HTML files would execute and steal data from the user's browser localStorage.
 In layman's terms, localStorage is a term that describes a local container in the user's browser where data about a web application is stored.

bleeping-3.doc:
More than a third of the websites you visit online may include an outdated JavaScript library that's vulnerable to one or more security flaws.
 This is the conclusion of recent research carried out by a team of six scientists from the College of Computer and Information Science at Northeastern University, who scanned over 133,000 domains and found that 37% loaded outdated and insecure JavaScript libraries.
 Scan methodology
 The JavaScript ecosystem is the largest in the world, and the npm repository includes nearly 100,000 libraries. The scan did not cover all, but only 72 of the most popular JavaScript projects, such as jQuery, Angular, Handlebars, Bootstrap, Modernizr, Moment, LoDash, and others.
 To assess the state of each library, researchers also built their own database of vulnerabilities for the selected JavaScript projects.

capability: vulnerable to one or more security flaws

bleeping-4.doc:
Since the Cerber Ransomware was first released back in early March of 2016, this ransomware would not only encrypt your files, but would also annoyingly encrypt the file names as well. This made it difficult for users and administrators to determine what files were actually encrypted and restore them from backups.
 While many variants of Cerber have been released over time, this "feature" has always remained the same. That is until today, when both Emsisoft researcher Sarah, otherwise known as xXToffeeXx, and SwiftOnSecurity found a new sample of Cerber that leaves the original filename the same and only appends a random extension as shown below.


 Cerber Encrypted Files


As you can see from the above picture, this new variant will keep the original filename, but now append a random extension to the filename. According to Sarah, this extension will be the same for all files encrypted on a particular machine, but will be different from machine to machine.

bleeping-5.doc:
Version 57 of the Google Chrome for Android, Chrome OS, Linux, Mac, and Windows is available for download, or update, using the browser's built-in update feature.
 Chrome's new release comes with two new main features, a host of improvements to existing browser APIs, and 36 security fixes.
 The biggest addition to Chrome 57 is support for WebAssembly, a new standard for packing and delivering web pages. We've already gone through WebAssembly's major benefits in a previous story, two days ago, when Firefox 52 became the first browser to offer WebAssembly support in its stable branch.
 CSS Grid Layout
 The other major feature in Chrome 57 is actually a big deal for developers.

bleeping-6.doc:
For many years, MAC Address Randomization was slated as the next big thing for protecting user privacy on the modern Internet.
 The standard, which works by deploying a new MAC address to a device in order to break down user tracking attempts, is still under development at the IEEE (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) and has already passed a few security tests.
 Attack breaks MAC Address Randomization on all devices
 Now, four scholars from the US Naval Academy say they've managed to track 100% of all test smartphones, despite the devices using randomized MAC addresses.
 The technique worked across all tested manufacturers, and the researchers say this was possible because of a previously unknown flaw in the way wireless chipsets handle low-level control frames.
 Their work was based on previous research released in 2016 by researchers from Belgium and France, who used a similar technique to track 50% of tested smartphones, despite using MAC address randomization.

bleeping-8.doc:
Today Microsoft released Insider Preview Build 15055 to PC and Mobile insiders on the fast ring, Like the previous release, this release focuses on fixing bugs and does not provide any new features.
 Of particular note, are the resolution of installation issues that people were experiencing in previous builds. Below is the full list of changes in this version.
 Other changes, improvements, and fixes for PC

 If you have Symantec/Norton anti-virus software installed on your PC, you should no longer get an 0x80070228 error when attempting to download this build. Symantec released updated anti-virus definitions last week that fixes this issue.

bleeping-11.doc:
Willem de Groot, a Dutch security expert, is asking owners of defunct or soon-to-be-dead online stores to donate their domains so he can set up honeypots and track credit card stealing malware and other types of cyber-attacks on e-commerce targets.
 De Groot, who is also the co-founder of Byte.nl, a web hosting service, and founder of MageReport, a security scanner for Magento shops, says he needs store owners to donate their former domains because classic honeypots won't work against web malware, and in particular against variants targeting online stores.
 Honeypots are servers that are configured to behave like various types of applications, but they also run monitoring software that logs any attempts to exploit security weaknesses.
 E-commerce honeypots aren't always efficient
 For online stores, setting up a honeypot server implies creating a store from scratch. This is useless, de Groot says, as the store won't have any search engine presence, and attackers could easily detect this.

bleeping-12.doc:
WikiLeaks dumped 12 new documents today that provide a more in-depth look at the hacking techniques the CIA allegedly used to hack Apple devices, such as Macs and iPhones.
 This dump, which WikiLeaks identifies under the Dark Matter codename, is part of a series of dumps called Vault 7, which WikiLeaks claims are hacking tools obtained from the CIA.
 The first Vault 7 dump, named Year Zero, came to light at the start of March and included wiki pages from the CIA's intranet, containing documentation for some of the CIA's cyber-weapons.
 Dark Matter includes details on lots of EFI/UEFI implants
 Included in this original leak were documents related to CIA's alleged arsenal of OS X and iOS hacking tools. Today's Dark Matter dump provides 12 new documents that contain a lot more information on those tools.

capability: alleged arsenal of OS X and iOS hacking tools

bleeping-14.doc:
Some of the malicious Android Minecraft mods (ESET)


News of malicious Android apps hosted on the Google Play Store doesn't seem to stop coming these days, as ESET and Zscaler researchers recently disclosed they've reported nearly 100 malicious apps they recently come across.
 The biggest batch comes from ESET security researcher Lukas Stefanko, who says that between March 16 and 21, he reported to Google 87 Android apps posing as Minecraft mods, but which, in reality, contained two malware (adware) strains.
 In total, the researcher says, the apps reached up to 990,000 installs before Google took them down.
 None of the apps contained any Minecraft functionality
 Stefanko says that none of these apps contained any legitimate functionality, being mere vessels for adware. The apps would only work during the installation process, focusing on luring the user into granting them admin privileges.

capability: 87 Android apps posing as Minecraft mods

bleeping-15.doc:
As everyone kind of expected, Google Chrome, the world's leading browser with a comfortable market share of above 50%, is also the most installed software package.
 This is one of several findings of a report from Czech security giant Avast, which aggregated anonymous usage data from a whopping of 116 million PCs.
 According to Avast, second to Google Chrome in term of the number of active installs is Adobe's Reader app, followed by Flash Player (Active X version). The rest of the top 10 is made up by Firefox, the Flash Player Plugin, Skype, VLC Player, WinRAR, Java, and Adobe AIR.

 The data from Avast's report was gathered via AVG TuneUp’s Automatic Software Updater feature, therefore, it also included details on the version number of each software package.
 More than half of active software installs are out-of-date

bleeping-16.doc:
Security researcher Dylan Ayrey detailed last week a new web-based attack named XSSJacking that combines three other techniques  — Clickjacking, Pastejacking, and Self-XSS — to steal data from careless users.
 Ayrey says XSSJacking can help attackers reach sensitive information for which they would normally need a more complex security flaw, such as a stored XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) or CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery), issues which most websites tend to fix when reported.
 The attack is not fully-automated, as it still relies on social engineering, a reason why many of today's security bug bounty programs won't even consider it as a security flaw, Ayrey told Bleeping Computer in an email.
 Some conditions must be met fo XSSJacking attacks
 For an XSSJacking attack to take place, some conditions must be met, but in hindsight, all attacks, even CSRF and SQL injections, all need one or more special conditions.
 For example, in the case of XSSJacking, the target website must be vulnerable to clickjacking.

bleeping-17.doc:
A botnet specialized in gift card fraud is using the infrastructure of nearly 1,000 websites to check the balance of several types of electronic gift cards in order to defraud legitimate card owners.
 Distil Networks, a cybersecurity firm specialized in bot attack detection, monitoring, and mitigation, says the botnet, nicknamed GiftGhostBot, has started attacks on February 26, this year.
 Attacks aimed at online stores
 The operators of this botnet aimed their attacks at the infrastructure embedded in some of the targeted websites, most of which are online stores.
 These websites allow their customers to buy products with gift cards, and support end points for interacting with the card's issuer.
 Operators of the GiftGhostBot botnet launch brute-force attacks against these endpoints.

bleeping-18.doc:
Lots and lots of little crappy ransomware released this week with nothing new or innovative. We do have some interesting Spora stats, lots of new Jigsaw variants, a story on the decline of Locky, and of course an updated decryptor by Fabian Wosar who continues to kick ransomware in the buttocks. Other than that, not really any of significance.
 Contributors and those who provided new ransomware information and stories this week include: @malwrhunterteam, @PolarToffee, @fwosar, @struppigel, @demonslay335,  @malwareforme, @jorntvdw, @FourOctets, DanielGallagher, @campuscodi, @JAMESWT_MHT, @Seifreed, @JakubKroustek, @BleepinComputer, @erpscan, @barklyprotects. 
 If you are interested in ransomware or InfoSec, I suggest you follow them on Twitter.
 March 18th 2017

bleeping-19.doc:
During the past year, Let's Encrypt has issued a total of 15,270 SSL certificates that contained the word "PayPal" in the domain name or the certificate identity.
 Of these, approximately 14,766 (96.7%) were issued for domains that hosted phishing sites, according to an analysis carried out on a small sample of 1,000 domains, by Vincent Lynch, encryption expert for The SSL Store.
 Security experts have warned of Let's Encrypt abuse
 Lynch's analysis comes to confirm some of the fears voiced as early as 2015, around Let's Encrypt's early launch phase.
 Encryption and infosec experts warned that by providing free SSL certificates; phishers, tech support scammers, and other malware authors would flock to obtain free certificates and move their operations on HTTPS domains.
 The first of these security incidents was a malvertising campaign that used

bleeping-20.doc:
Yesterday, Google announced plans to completely shut down the Google Talk service after June 26, 2017.
 Google Talk, often referred to by its unofficial names of Gchat, Gtalk, or Gmail Chat, was launched in 2005, one year after Google launched Gmail, and was available as a desktop client and mobile app, but also as a web-based service embedded in the Gmail inbox.
 Google started phasing out Google Talk in 2015
 In February 2015, Google shut down most of the desktop and mobile clients and recommended users to move to its newer Google Hangouts service.
 In spite of the announcement, Google left Talk server running, and many users just switched to XMPP clients like Adium, Gajim, or Pidgin to talk to their friends.
 Now, Google will bring the final ax over Google Talk's head on June 26.

bleeping-21.doc:
The browser wars are starting to heat up again as both Google and Microsoft promote their software at the expense of their competitors. Such is the case with a new notification shown in the Chrome Web Store telling Microsoft Edge users to switch to Google Chrome.
 Earlier this month, Microsoft started to display promotions in the Windows 10 Start Menu that suggest Firefox users should switch to the Microsoft Edge browser.

 Windows 10 Start Menu Promoting Microsoft Edge
 Now we have the Chrome Web Store telling Microsoft Edge users that they should switch to Google Chrome for better security.

bleeping-22.doc:
An archive with over 10 million records of guests at the MGM Resorts hotels is currently distributed for free on a hacking forum.
 The data comes from a security breach in July 2019 on one of MGM cloud services. In total, there are 10,683,189 records with about 3.1 million unique email addresses as far back as 2017.
 Some data still valid
 Among the details compromised are guests' names, dates of birth, email addresses, phone numbers, and physical addresses complete with postal codes.
 The post sharing the information was spotted by a researcher at Under the Breach, a company that monitors the cybercrime space and currently working on releasing a new service aiming to provide companies intelligence about potential breaches.

bleeping-23.doc:
Security researchers discovered a new batch of nine websites infected with malicious JavaScript that steals payment card info from online shoppers.
 Some of them were infected a second time and the script persisted, despite efforts from the researchers to contact the website owners.
 The script is attributed to MageCart Group 12, as per extensive analysis from RiskIQ a threat actor that is changing tactics as their tricks are being published in security reports.
 Code obfuscation does not help
More recent activity linked to this actor was documented by researchers Jacob Pimental and Max Kersten towards the end of January when they published details about two sports events ticket resellers running card skimming code.
 The two researchers noticed that the skimmer is hosted on 'toplevelstatic.com,' which resolves to multiple IP addresses, mostly in Russia.

 "

bleeping-24.doc:
The number of WhatsApp phishing URLs has skyrocketed in Q4 2019 after a 13,467.6% huge QoQ surge in the number of unique phishing URLs targeting its users being discovered by email security company Vade Secure since Q3 2019.
 Vade Secure's Phishers' Favorites report for Q4 2019 highlights the 25 most impersonated brands in phishing attacks with the list being compiled after examining phishing URLs detected by Vade Secure's technology. 
 "Leveraging data from more than 600 million protected mailboxes worldwide, Vade's machine learning algorithms identify the brands being impersonated as part of its real-time analysis of the URL and page content," Vade Secure says. 
 WhatsApp's 5,020 unique phishing URLs detected by Vade Secure and its ascent as the 5th most impersonated brand in phishing attacks (up 63 spots) was the driving force behind social media brands' increase in the share of URLs used in phishing attacks from 13.1% in Q3 to 24.1% in Q4 2019.
 Vade Secure explains that "the staggering growth in phishing URLs stems primarily from a campaign inviting recipients to the so-called Berbagi WhatsApp group, which advertises pornographic content.
 "Moreover, it appears web hosting provider 000webhost was hacked and used to host the phishing pages.

bleeping-25.doc:
The FTC has begun to issue refunds to people who were convinced into purchasing computer repair services at Office Depot based on fake malware scans.
 Between 2009 and November 2016, Office Depot and Office Max employees utilized a diagnostic program called 'PC Health Check' that would in many cases report a person's computer had malware even if it was not infected.

 PC Health Check software interface
 Whistleblowers told KIRO7 reporters that the employees were pressured into utilizing PC Health Check even though it was known to not be accurate to convince people to purchase repair services ranging from $180 to $300.
 KIRO7 reporters tested this by taking six brand new laptops to various Office Depot locations, where they were falsely told four out of the six laptops were infected and were prompted to purchase repair services.
 Office Depot settles with the FTC

bleeping-26.doc:
Microsoft has started rolling out new Fluent-based icons for Windows 10 apps and system applications to Insiders on the Fast Ring.
 Starting today with the Windows 10 Mail and Calendar icons, Microsoft is slowly releasing new updated and colorful icons to users running Windows 10 Insider builds

 Evolution of the Windows Mail Icon
 These icons will be phased in over the next couple of months through app updates via the Microsoft Store and via release previews of Windows 10.
 Windows 10 Insiders in the Fast Ring will start to see the new icons sooner as they are pushed out in new versions of apps being tested by Insiders.
 As reported by Aggiornamentilumia.it, for some people these icons have already started rolling out to Insider builds.

bleeping-27.doc:
Google is facing a new lawsuit for allegedly using its Google for Education platform to gather the personal and private data from students under the age of thirteen.
 As part of the Google for Education platform, United States schools are offered free Google Chromebooks and access to the G Suite for Education service.
 This service gives students access to Gmail, Classroom, online word processing, and presentation applications to do schoolwork, homework, communicate with teachers and submit assignments.
 To comply with Children'S Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA), online platforms are required to get the parental consent of children under the age of 13 before allowing them to use their service or gather information about them.
 In a lawsuit filed Thursday, New Mexico Attorney General Hector Balderas states that Google is allegedly attempting to bypass this law through Google Education to mine the data of the students who use it.
 "Outside of its Google Education platform, Google forbids children under the age of 13 in the United States from having their own Google accounts.

bleeping-28.doc:
Google reacted severely against nearly 600 Android apps in Play Store that were violating two ad-related policies by kicking them out of the repository.
 The penalty went further with banning the apps from the company's ad monetization platforms (Google AdMob and Google Ad Manager), essentially cutting authors any hope of getting revenue from their apps through Google.
 Ad-serving principles
 In an announcement today, the company explains that offensive apps featured advertisements in a way that was in contrast with the disruptive ads and disallowed interstitial policies.
 The two principles infringed ensure smooth user experience and help combat mobile the many forms of ad fraud, including harmless apps that disobey the rules.
 When referring to disruptive ads, Google describes them as displayed in a way that could cause the user to click them unintentionally.

bleeping-29.doc:
If you are using older Intel processors or AMD processors, you can boost the performance of Windows 10 by enabling the Retpoline Spectre mitigations that were recently ported to Windows 10 October 2018 Update build 1809.
 In order to mitigate the Spectre vulnerabilities in Windows 10, Microsoft had introduced fixes that caused a performance decrease, which were more noticeable in older CPUs.   To resolve these performance issues, Microsoft has been testing a new mitigation technique called Retpoline in Windows Insider Preview builds since build 18272.
 This mitigation has recently been backported to Windows 10 October 2018 Update build 1809, but is being slowly rolled out over time as they test its performance in large-scale public use. If you do not want to wait, you can use the instructions below to enable it immediately on supported processors.

bleeping-30.doc:
Screenshots of Microsoft's in-house Edge Chromium-based web browser have leaked online, showing the large amounts of user interface DNA the two browsers share with each other and providing details on a future Microsoft Edge Store.
 Microsoft announced during early December that they will be giving up on the current code base of their Microsoft Edge browser switching to Google's open-source Chromium and that the nametag will remain unchanged even though the app will be a whole different beast inside and outside.
 Since then there were no other details released about the project through official channels, however, as it usually happens with projects developed behind closed doors, there were a number of leaks allowing us to get a glimpse of what the end product will look like.

 After app icons and some installer screenshots of the new Edge browser have been leaked at the end of February, Neowin also published a set of leaked snapshots of an in-house test preview build of the Chromium-based Edge on March 5.
 The screenshots show that Microsoft's new Edge will share a lot with Google's Chrome on the user interface side, but it will also come with a number of unique features such as an integrated news feed powered by Microsoft News, Bing as the default search engine, and Microsoft accounts used for syncing.  
 While Redmond previously confirmed that the new Chromium-based Edge should support current Chrome extensions, the leaked screenshots of this Chromium-based Edge build designed for internal testing show that the browser will come with its own Microsoft Edge Store.

bleeping-31.doc:
Microsoft has released Windows 10 Insider Preview Build 18351 for Insiders in the Fast ring. As the 19H1 builds move closer to being released, we should expect to see only bug fixes and no new major features being added to this development branch.
 If you are a Windows Insider in the Fast ring, you can update to the Insider Preview Build 18351 by going into  Settings ->  Update & Security -> Windows Update and then checking for new updates.


 Windows 10 Insider Preview Build 18351

bleeping-32.doc:
With the high ransom prices and big payouts of enterprise-targeting ransomware, we now have another ransomware known as Mailto or Netwalker that is compromising enterprise networks and encrypting all of the Windows devices connected to it.
 In August 2019 a new ransomware was spotted in ID Ransomware that was named Mailto based on the extension that was appended to encrypted files.
 It was not known until today when the Australian Toll Group disclosed that their network was attacked by the Mailto ransomware, that we discovered that this ransomware is targeting the enterprise.
 It should be noted that the ransomware has been commonly called the Mailto Ransomware due to the appended extension, but analysis of one of its decryptors indicates that it is named Netwalker.   We will discuss this later in the article.
 The Mailto / Netwalker ransomware

bleeping-33.doc:
Medicaid coordinated care organization (CCO) Health Share of Oregon today disclosed a data breach exposing the health and personal info of 654,362 individuals following the theft of a laptop owned by its transportation vendor GridWorks IC.
 The non-profit organization is Oregon's largest Medicaid CCO and it serves the Oregon Health Plan (Medicaid) members in Clackamas, Multnomah, and Washington counties.
 "On January 2, 2020, Health Share of Oregon learned that the personal information of its members was located on a laptop stolen from GridWorks IC, Health Share's contracted non-emergent medical transportation (Ride to Care) vendor," says the CCO in a statement issued today.
 "The break-in and theft occurred at GridWorks' office on November 18, 2019. "
 Data breach exposes personal and health information

victim: Medicaid coordinated care organization (CCO) Health Share of Oregon

bleeping-34.doc:
Security researchers taking a closer look at the Philips Hue smart bulbs and the bridge device that connects them discovered a vulnerability that helped them compromise more meaningful systems on the local network.
 The security flaw was discovered is in the ZigBee wireless communication protocol that is used by a wide range of smart home devices.
 From bulb to bridge to network
 Tracked as CVE-2020-6007, the bug has a severity score of 7.9 out of 10. It is a heap buffer overflow that can be exploited remotely in Philips Hue Bridge model 2.x to execute arbitrary code. Affected firmware versions are up to 1935144020, released on January 13.

bleeping-37.doc:
The attackers behind the RobbinHood Ransomware are exploiting a vulnerable GIGABYTE driver to install a malicious and unsigned driver into Windows that is used to terminate antivirus and security software.
 When performing a network-wide compromise, ransomware attackers need to push out a ransomware executable as quickly as possible and to as many systems as they can to avoid being detected.
 One protection that can get in their way of a successful attack, though, is antivirus software running on a workstation that removes the ransomware executable before it can be executed.
 To overcome this hurdle, the operators behind the RobbinHood Ransomware are utilizing a custom antivirus killing package that is pushed out to workstations to prepare it for encryption.
 Using trusted drivers to terminate security processes
Most Windows security software processes are protected from being terminated by regular processes and can only be terminated by Kernel drivers, which have the highest permission possible in Windows.
 To better secure Windows, Microsoft added a driver signature enforcement policy that prevents the installation of Windows Kernel drivers unless they have been cosigned by Microsoft.

bleeping-38.doc:
The U.S. Department of Justice (DoJ) today issued a notification to raise awareness among victims of the Quantum Stresser Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) for-hire service operated by David Bukoski.
 DDoS-for-hire services known as booters or stressers are used by malicious actors, pranksters, or hacktivists to launch large-scale DDoS cyberattacks against a targeted site or online service, triggering a denial of service that leads to the service being taken down or working a lot slower than usual.
 "Due to the large number of potential victims in this case, Chief U.S. District Judge Timothy M. Burgess issued an order directing the government to employ alternative victim notification procedures so that any member of the community at large who believes they may be a crime victim is made aware of their potential rights," the DoJ statement says.
 "The government is asking that members of the community who believe they may be a victim of Bukoski’s criminal activities, to please contact (907) 271-3041 to reach the Victim-Witness Unit at the U.S. Attorney’s Office, District of Alaska."
 This notification was the result of a motion for alternative victim notification filed on February 3 which also says that there are "plans to notify –   to the extent possible – those ISPs providing services to victim networks, who may be able to conduct additional notification of their own customers. "
 The DoJ has scheduled a restitution hearing on May 5, 2020, at 10:30 A.M. in Anchorage.

bleeping-39.doc:
Android users are targeted in a phishing campaign that will infect their devices with the Anubis banking Trojan that can steal financial information from more than 250 banking and shopping applications.
 The campaign uses a devious method to get the potential victims to install the malware on their devices: it asks them to enable Google Play Protect while actually disabling it after being granted permissions on the device.
 To deliver the malware, the attackers use a malicious link embedded within the phishing email that will download an APK file camouflaged as an invoice as Cofense found.
 After being asked if he wants to use Google Play Protect and installing the downloaded APK, the victim's device will be infected with the Anubis Trojan.

 Google Play Protect used as cover (Cofense)
 Targets over 250 financial applications

bleeping-41.doc:
Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is once again warning its customers that certain Serial-Attached SCSI solid-state drives will fail after 40,000 hours of operation, unless a critical patch is applied.
 The company made a similar announcement in November 2019, when firmware defect produced failure after 32,768 hours of running.
 Affected drives
 The current issue affects drives in HPE server and Storage products like HPE ProLiant, Synergy, Apollo 4200, Synergy Storage Modules, D3000 Storage Enclosure, StoreEasy 1000 Storage.
 HPE Model Number

 This deal is for a bundle that contains 3 courses and over 50 hours of training for the Cisco's CCNA certification exam track. This bundle normally has a value of $897, but has been discounted 96% to $29 as part of this deal. 
 Please note that exam vouchers are not included with this deal.
